content: The Act titled "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009" highlights the importance of individuals standing up for their rights and beliefs, as demonstrated by the Civil Rights movement in the 1950s and 1960s through events like the Montgomery Bus Boycott, sit-ins, Freedom Rides, March on Washington, and the drive for voting rights in Mississippi and Selma. The Civil Rights movement, with events like the Montgomery Bus Boycott, sit-ins, Freedom Rides, March on Washington, and voting rights drive in Mississippi and Selma, had visible leaders like Thurgood Marshall, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and Rosa Parks. However, many other lesser-known individuals played crucial roles. Participants in the movement hold valuable first-hand memories that are essential for preserving the history of the era. (4) Participants in the Civil Rights movement have valuable first-hand memories that can provide a detailed history of the era. Recording their stories will preserve their struggle and sacrifice for future generations. (5) A Federal project to collect oral histories from Civil Rights activists is crucial for educating future generations through primary-source material. A Federal project is needed to collect oral histories from Civil Rights activists to preserve their struggle and sacrifice for future generations. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution are suitable repositories for this primary-source material. The purpose of this Act is to create a federally sponsored project to collect video and audio oral histories from Civil Rights activists. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution will preserve and make these oral histories available to the public. The Act aims to create a federally sponsored project to collect video and audio recordings of personal histories from individuals involved in the American Civil Rights movement. This project will coordinate at a national level and complement existing documentary work, preserving the memories of these individuals for future generations to appreciate their sacrifices. The Act establishes a joint project at the Library of Congress and National Museum of African American History and Culture to collect video and audio recordings of participants in the American Civil Rights Movement. This project aims to preserve the memories of individuals involved in the movement for future generations to appreciate their sacrifices. The Librarian of Congress and the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution will establish an oral history project to collect audio and video recordings of participants in the American Civil Rights Movement. This project aims to preserve the memories of individuals involved in the movement. The project aims to survey collections of audio and video recordings of Civil Rights movement participants to avoid duplication of efforts. It also involves collecting personal histories and testimonials to complement existing documentary work. The project aims to collect video and audio recordings, as well as visual and written materials related to personal histories of Civil Rights movement participants. The materials will be cataloged, indexed, and made available for public use. The project aims to collect recordings and materials related to personal histories of Civil Rights movement participants. The collection will be cataloged, indexed, and made available for public use through the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Secretary will oversee these duties through the Director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Secretary will carry out duties through the Director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture, using agreements and partnerships with other entities for activities described in the Act. The Librarian and the Secretary may procure services and accept volunteer assistance to develop guidelines for acquiring recordings under the project. The Librarian and the Secretary may procure temporary services, accept volunteer assistance, and make advance payments for collecting video and audio recordings under the project. The Librarian and the Secretary will collect video and audio recordings and materials related to the Civil Rights movement as soon as possible after the enactment of the Act, starting with recordings from the oldest individuals involved. The Act defines the Civil Rights movement as the movement for racial equality in the United States from 1954 to 1968, which challenged racial segregation and achieved equal rights legislation for all American citizens. The Civil Rights movement aimed to secure racial equality in the United States for African Americans from 1954 to 1968, challenging racial segregation and achieving equal rights legislation for all citizens. The Librarian of Congress and the Secretary are encouraged to solicit donations to support activities related to Civil Rights history. The Librarian of Congress can accept donations of funds and in-kind contributions to support activities under section 3. Any funds donated for this purpose will be deposited into a dedicated account and used solely to support these activities. The Librarian cannot deposit any funds not intended for this exclusive purpose. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. SEC. 5.
